Y. M. C. A. PRESIDENT

Y. M. C. A. at a banquet of

The election for this position
will take place at the "Y" office on Tuesday.

dinner was the Reverend John
C. Fleck, of St. John's Lutheran Church. Mr. Herman
Bell entertained with several
selections on the musical saw.

Athletic Board To
Conduct Tea Dances
Tea dances after lacrosse games
this year, will be promoted by the
Athletic Association Board, it was
announced a few days ago. The
dances will be conducted in the same
manner as last year, except that the
A. A. Board will be in charge in
place of the Cotillon Club.
A committee consisting of Norman Keyes, chairman, Albert Abraham, and George Helfrich, have
been put in charge of arrangements.
According to Keyes, the dances will
continue during the entire spring
sports season if the patronage warrants. As usual the Black and Blue
Jays will furnish music for the
weekly affairs.

One hundred and twenty-six dollars and forty cents is the sum total of damages to table linen, dishes,
Silverware and furniture at the
freshman banquet in Annapolis,
last week. This fact was revealed
when Mr. J. P. Guienot, proprietor
of Guienot's Lunch Room and caterer, tendered a bill to the treastirers of the sophomore and freshroan classes.
Forty-two dinner plates which
smashed against the walls and floor
(If the State Armory totalled almost
fourteen dollars. Sixty-four tumblers, t*enty:eight soup plates,
twenty-six cups, thirty-one platters,
twenty-eight saucers and four sugar

bowls brought the crockery damage
tip to nearly seventy dollars.
•
Frosh and sophs have also been
assessed eight dollars for three ,table cloths that were reduced to
shreds while the cost of smashing
twelve chairs and several tables into kindling wood is estimated at
thirty-six dollars.
•

Season Most Unsuccessful in History of
TONIGHT AND TOMORROW
Sport at Hopkins; Hiss, Stone and
Stewart High Scorers

Donald Hiss, high point scorer
for the season, stellar back stroke
artist, and one of the two new men
to be awarded a letter this year, was
elected captain of next year's swimming team at a meeting held last
Saturday night after the final meet
of the season with Delaware.
"Woody" Welsh, the only other new
swimmer to win an award, won his
letter in this meet by winning the
50 yard dash.
The swimming season, which
closed with last Saturday's defeat by
Delaware, ended the Jay mermen's
first entirely unsuccessful season
since the institution of the sport at
Hopkins. All five meets, Army,
Catholic University, Rutgers, Brown
and Delaware, resulted in defeats,
though some were lost by very scant
margins.

WE DRESS UP!
Once more the entire student body digs out its student activicards
ties
and its tuxedos and goes to the Lyric. Once more boys
stop being boys, and masquerade as their sisters or sweethearts.
Once more the Barnstormers storm. Everybody goes, and nearly
everybody applauds, even those who did not make major parts
and were too effervescent with pride to be "gentlemen."
We're all happy, and even though the Barnstormers do not
give as good a performance as usual, we all enjoy ourselves. The
performance is always, however, "better than last year's," so there
is even less chance of not having a good time.
As the preparation necessary for the two presentations is
probably more than for any other accomplishment of students
during the year, the Barnstormers stake their all upon tonight
and tomorrow night. We wish them luck.

A GOOD MOVE
As the poor Athletic Association needs every cent .that it
can get its hands on, the decision to transfer the Saturday afternoon tea dances from the auspices of the Cotillon Club to the
Athletic Association will be in the nature of a boon. The profits

Ripple of muscles, running free;
Dip of a paddle, deep and true;
Sun on my shoulders, kissing me.
Joy of lying beneath a tree;
Sailing clouds in the endless blue,
Like sail-boats on an azure sea.
Moon in my face caressing me;
Deep vault of heaven sprinkled thick
With star-points, cold and calm and true;—
Summer—nothing I must do.

The opinions of youth are tenacious, whether or not they can
be logically defended. An attempt to defend idleness, to contradict the necessity 'of achievement, to prove that nothing matters
but happiness, and that happiness is largely freedom from unpleasant work—one cannot convince one's "superiors" of these
things. But they are obviously true. They were true to our
"superiors" when they had the wisdom of youth. I know they
are true. Boyhood summers, with their idyllic idleness, are happiness; to lie on a baking beach, with white birds swimming in a
blue sky and kids swimming in a blue bay—that was once happiness for me.
Work—why must I work? Because I can't get thru college
without working. And I must go to college to enable me to work
better afterwards. Silly . . . Afterwards . . . I wonder. .
Free spirit. Nature, I think, is but a background for emotion. Personal freedom, then, against the backgrounds of beautiful
environment, would allow emotional freedom, which is the basis of
happiness. It will constitute always my greatest happiness. To
drop my mask without fear. I have done that only twice since
I was twelve, and now I see the charm of playing with fire—until
burned. Now,—and I doubt if it is an universal case—my mask
is far more popular than I could ever be. Drunkenness never
reveals anyone; it accents the features of the false face. That
is because we all get surrounded by prohibitions—"gets" we don't
want and "wants" we don't get. And fear of being caught unmasked.
Afterwards ... either an old man reaching for the pleasures
of youth, or an older stupider man who laughs at youth. A great
many sensitive souls become one of these types simply thru fear
of being young in youth. . .. I despise age masquerading. Hate
it with the unreasoning hatred of youth. And having grown old,
if I masqueraded, I should know how youth hated me.
Money, money, money. That is why they work—these hypocrites who desire "achievement," money to buy themselves a pittance of idleness, more money to buy less work. Money is the
reason for art, literature, music. That, and esteem. Any work
of art done for the sake of achievement alone would be destroyed
on its completion, the constructive urge having been filled, there
would be no 'need for it. Money to do nothing. Or else the continuous labor of those who by working have killed the faculties for
happiness. I too shall buy a chunk of idleness; but I shall purchase cheap sections frequently rather than store it all up for my
deadened anecdotage. One's Afterwards should begin at about
twenty-three. At this age one should begin to be idle; to grab
youth until the aging of the body intervened.
What is my reason for writing this? None—emphatically,
if you are cruel. Yet the self-esteem I may unreasonably derive
from it is an incidental thing. It is not happiness;—only the urge
of the word "do." It is a fine word. One always "does," whether
one works or not. To do what you please, no matter why. There
are two things in the work which I desire,—love, which is the
fruit of idleness, and idleness, which is right to love.

WE DRESS UP!
Once more the entire student body digs out its student activicards
ties
and its tuxedos and goes to the Lyric. Once more boys
stop being boys, and masquerade as their sisters or sweethearts.
Once more the Barnstormers storm. Everybody goes, and nearly
everybody applauds, even those who did not make major parts
and were too effervescent with pride to be "gentlemen."
We're all happy, and even though the Barnstormers do not
give as good a performance as usual, we all enjoy ourselves. The
performance is always, however, "better than last year's," so there
is even less chance of not having a good time.
As the preparation necessary for the two presentations is
probably more than for any other accomplishment of students
during the year, the Barnstormers stake their all upon tonight
and tomorrow night. We wish them luck.

A GOOD MOVE
As the poor Athletic Association needs every cent .that it
can get its hands on, the decision to transfer the Saturday afternoon tea dances from the auspices of the Cotillon Club to the
Athletic Association will be in the nature of a boon. The profits

Ripple of muscles, running free;
Dip of a paddle, deep and true;
Sun on my shoulders, kissing me.
Joy of lying beneath a tree;
Sailing clouds in the endless blue,
Like sail-boats on an azure sea.
Moon in my face caressing me;
Deep vault of heaven sprinkled thick
With star-points, cold and calm and true;—
Summer—nothing I must do.

The opinions of youth are tenacious, whether or not they can
be logically defended. An attempt to defend idleness, to contradict the necessity 'of achievement, to prove that nothing matters
but happiness, and that happiness is largely freedom from unpleasant work—one cannot convince one's "superiors" of these
things. But they are obviously true. They were true to our
"superiors" when they had the wisdom of youth. I know they
are true. Boyhood summers, with their idyllic idleness, are happiness; to lie on a baking beach, with white birds swimming in a
blue sky and kids swimming in a blue bay—that was once happiness for me.
Work—why must I work? Because I can't get thru college
without working. And I must go to college to enable me to work
better afterwards. Silly . . . Afterwards . . . I wonder. .
Free spirit. Nature, I think, is but a background for emotion. Personal freedom, then, against the backgrounds of beautiful
environment, would allow emotional freedom, which is the basis of
happiness. It will constitute always my greatest happiness. To
drop my mask without fear. I have done that only twice since
I was twelve, and now I see the charm of playing with fire—until
burned. Now,—and I doubt if it is an universal case—my mask
is far more popular than I could ever be. Drunkenness never
reveals anyone; it accents the features of the false face. That
is because we all get surrounded by prohibitions—"gets" we don't
want and "wants" we don't get. And fear of being caught unmasked.
Afterwards ... either an old man reaching for the pleasures
of youth, or an older stupider man who laughs at youth. A great
many sensitive souls become one of these types simply thru fear
of being young in youth. . .. I despise age masquerading. Hate
it with the unreasoning hatred of youth. And having grown old,
if I masqueraded, I should know how youth hated me.
Money, money, money. That is why they work—these hypocrites who desire "achievement," money to buy themselves a pittance of idleness, more money to buy less work. Money is the
reason for art, literature, music. That, and esteem. Any work
of art done for the sake of achievement alone would be destroyed
on its completion, the constructive urge having been filled, there
would be no 'need for it. Money to do nothing. Or else the continuous labor of those who by working have killed the faculties for
happiness. I too shall buy a chunk of idleness; but I shall purchase cheap sections frequently rather than store it all up for my
deadened anecdotage. One's Afterwards should begin at about
twenty-three. At this age one should begin to be idle; to grab
youth until the aging of the body intervened.
What is my reason for writing this? None—emphatically,
if you are cruel. Yet the self-esteem I may unreasonably derive
from it is an incidental thing. It is not happiness;—only the urge
of the word "do." It is a fine word. One always "does," whether
one works or not. To do what you please, no matter why. There
are two things in the work which I desire,—love, which is the
fruit of idleness, and idleness, which is right to love.
